content:
Page 51: References

* National Council of Teachers of Mathematics. (2020). Principles to Actions: Ensuring Mathematical Success for All. Reston, VA: Author.
* Strogatz, S. H. (2014). The Joy of x: A Guided Tour of Math, from One to Infinity. New York: Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.
* Swetz, F. J. (1987). The Sea Island Mathematical Manual: Surveying and Mathematics in Ancient China. University Park, PA: Pennsylvania State University Press.
* Weisstein, E. W. (Ed.). (2021). MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource. Retrieved March 12, 2023, from <http://mathworld.wolfram.com/>
* Wilson, R. M. (2002). Euler's Pioneering Equation: The Most Beautiful Theorem in Mathematics. Amherst, NY: Prometheus Books.
* Ziegler, G. M., & Aigner, M. (2010). Proofs from THE BOOK (4th ed.). Berlin: Springer.
* Morris Kline, Mathematics: The Loss of Certainty (Oxford University Press, 1980).
* G. Polya, How to Solve It (Princeton University Press, 1945).
* N. Koblitz, A Course in Number Theory and Cryptography (Springer, 1994).
* H. Steinhaus, Mathematical Snapshots (Oxford University Press, 1950).
* D. Burton, The History of Mathematics: An Introduction (McGraw Hill, 1989).
* T. Tao, Analysis I (Springer, 2006).
* J. Stewart, Calculus: Early Transcendentals (Brooks/Cole, 2011).
* D. Cox, Primes of the Form x^2 + ny^2 (Wiley, 1989).
* G. Strang, Linear Algebra and Its Applications (Academic Press, 2016).
* R. Penrose, The Road to Reality (Vintage, 2005).

These references provide a starting point for further exploration into the vast and diverse field of mathematics, and represent some of the most influential and insightful works in the subject.
